Consider the statement "All cats are mammals." Using predicate logic, translate this statement into a symbolic form and provide the truth value for the following predicate: 

P(x) : x is a cat
Q(x) : x is a mammal 

∀x(P(x) → Q(x))

What is the truth value of the above statement when x is the set of all mammals?
message_2:
The given statement "All cats are mammals" can be translated into predicate logic as ∀x(P(x) → Q(x)), where P(x) represents "x is a cat" and Q(x) represents "x is a mammal."

Now, we need to find the truth value of this statement when x is the set of all mammals.

For the statement ∀x(P(x) → Q(x)) to be true, it must hold for all elements in the set of all mammals. Since all cats are mammals, whenever P(x) is true (i.e., x is a cat), Q(x) will also be true (i.e., x is a mammal). For other mammals that are not cats, P(x) will be false, but the implication P(x) → Q(x) will still be true, because a false statement implies anything.

Therefore, the truth value of the statement ∀x(P(x) → Q(x)) when x is the set of all mammals is True.
